subject: Education
title: Waldorf Education: Imagination Before Information
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Waldorf Education: Imagination Before Information.

hook.text: At Waldorf schools, children don't read until age seven. And they do just fine.

buildup.text: Rudolf Steiner designed education around developmental phases: will, feeling, then thinking.

discovery.text: Arts, storytelling, and nature dominate early years; academics come later.

twist.text: Silicon Valley executives send their kids to Waldorf schoolsâ€”with zero technology.

climax.text: Research shows Waldorf students catch up academically and often surpass peers in creativity.

punchline.text: Sometimes slowing down early means going further later.

quiz.question: What is unique about Waldorf's approach to early education?
options: It prioritizes arts and imagination before formal academics
It introduces reading and math from age three
It relies heavily on digital learning tools
